block.p: MIDTOWN Civil Rights Heroes Inspiring Today's Students

Sixteen civil rights activists, most of whom live in New York, will be celebrated in an exhibition of historical and contemporary photographic portraits, graphic time lines, poetry and prose prepared in part by New York City public school students. The exhibition, ''The Long Walk to Freedom: Portraits of Civil Rights Activists Then and Now'' explores how ''ordinary'' people from varying racial and economic backgrounds came to accomplish extraordinary deeds through grass-roots organizing and sheer dedication.

The show is organized by Community Works, an organization that provides arts education programs to New York City public school students. Students from the Computer School on the West Side of Manhattan interviewed the 16 subjects for this exhibition. Sherifa Godfrey, one student participant, said: '' 'The Long Walk to Freedom' has changed my life. I now choose to do things that I never thought were possible.''

EAST SIDE Showcasing the Films Of Asian-American Artists

The latest work of renowned and emerging directors is appearing in the Asian American International Film Festival. There are dramas, documentaries and shorts, rare film screenings, filmmaking practice and discussion panels. Topics include Asian-American women in film, how to cast an Asian-American film, and strategies for distribution, marketing and digital production.
At left is a scene from ''Lies,'' Jang Sun-Woo's film about an obsessive love affair between a 35-year-old man and an 18-year-old woman, to be shown Friday at 6:30 p.m.

Asian American International Film Festival, today, Friday and Saturday, Florence Gould Hall/ French Institute, 59th Street and Madison Avenue; panels and workshops, $4 each; screening programs, $7.50 each; for full schedule, (212) 989-1422 or www.asiancinevision.org/.
MUSEUM MILE The Old Testament Vouches For Beer and Wine

You don't have to be of legal drinking age to enter ''Drink and Be Merry: Wine and Beer in Ancient Times,'' an exhibition at the Jewish Museum. The show consists of 180 objects of art and paraphernalia, including the Egyptian figurine of a woman brewing beer shown at right.
Most of the images are on loan from the Israel Museum in Jerusalem, which organized the show, and the Israel Antiquities Authority. Joseph E. Seagram & Sons is sponsor.
This exhibition examines methods of production and drinking customs involving wine and beer, both in religious and secular contexts, on special occasions and every day.

''Drink and Be Merry'' opens next Sunday through Nov. 5; Sunday, Monday, Wednesday and Thursday, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Tuesday 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue at 92nd Street; $8; students and people over 65, $5.50; children under 12, free; (212) 423-3200.
